channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Iran Set to Put Nuclear Deal in Motion After Guardian Council Ratification
item.description: The Guardian Council, an oversight panel with veto power, ratified a Parliament bill approving the nuclear pact, the last step needed.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Israel Bolsters Security in East Jerusalem After Violence
item.description: The authorities began setting up roadblocks and checkpoints and deployed police officers and soldiers, in response to what the government called a “wave of terrorism.”
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN and SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: Israeli police officers searched Palestinians and their vehicles at a checkpoint in the East Jerusalem neighborhood of Jabel Mukaber on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In China’s State News Media, What Is Said May Not Be What’s Printed
item.description: Several prominent China experts have recently reported instances in which the words attributed to them were fabricated or changed.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Britain Urges Saudis to Free Grandfather Facing 350 Lashes
item.description: The case of the grandfather, Karl Andree, who was arrested after the Saudi authorities found alcohol in his car, has become a matter of geopolitical controversy.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Karl Andree, 74, has been in a Saudi prison for over a year and faces 350 lashes because bottles of wine were found in his car.

item.title: Suicide Attack at Lawmaker’s Office in Pakistan Kills at Least 7
item.description: Four others were wounded in Punjab Province when the bomb detonated during a meeting with junior officials of the governing party, the police said.
item.dc:creator: WAQAR GILLANI
item.media:description: Rescue workers at the site of a suicide bombing in Taunsa, Pakistan, on Wednesday. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.

item.title: Magna Carta Exhibition in China Is Abruptly Moved From University
item.description: A public showing of one of the few surviving copies of the 13th-century document was shifted to the British ambassador’s residence, with no explanation given.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: An original copy of Magna Carta on view in New York City in 2007. Issued by King John of England in 1215, the document guaranteed the rights of individuals and held the ruler subject to the law.

item.title: Evzonoi Journal: Asylum Seekers Stir Commerce and Compassion in Greek Village
item.description: Thousands of migrants have stopped in Evzonoi, Greece, stimulating business at hotels and shops and inspiring acts of charity from residents.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Syrian refugee family shared the food they had just bought, along train tracks near Idomeni, a Greek village at the border with Macedonia. Some Greeks in the region say migrants' purchases have benefited businesses.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Europe’s Threat From Within
item.description: The refugee crisis might be an external challenge, but what really worries Brussels is the growing strength of the Continent’s regional separatists.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT ZARETSKY

item.title: Indonesian President Calls for Calm After Church Attack in Aceh
item.description: The appeal came after a man was fatally shot during a brawl set off by the razing of a Christian church.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Members of a Christian congregation waited as security forces investigated a church razing in Indonesia this week.

item.title: Australia Defends Plan to Kill Millions of Feral Cats
item.description: The country’s threatened species commissioner responded to celebrities’ concerns by saying the cats were “major contributors” to the extinction of mammal species.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: C. Potter/Department of the Environment, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A feral cat in Australia eating a bird.

item.title: Letter From America: Tax Plans of G.O.P. Favor the Rich Despite Populist Talk
item.description: For all their talk of anger and angst among working-class voters, Republican candidates have shied away from economic populism.
item.dc:creator: JOHN HARWOOD
item.media:description: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, a Republican presidential candidate, at an event last week. Mr. Rubio casts himself as a champion for Americans “living paycheck to paycheck.”

item.title: Taliban Waged a Calculated Campaign Against Women in Kunduz
item.description: Insurgents hounded women with public profiles, threatening them with violence if they returned to their jobs or homes, women who received the warnings said.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Hassina Sarwari, the Kunduz Province director of Women for Afghan Women, in 2014.

item.title: Philippine Military Says Kidnapping Video Appears to Be Authentic
item.description: The recording seems to show three foreigners and a woman from the Philippines seized at a resort last month, held by masked men with an Islamic State flag.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:description: A still image from a video believed to show four people taken hostage from a resort off the coast of Mindanao.

item.title: Obama Is Rethinking Pullout in Afghanistan, Officials Say
item.description: Leaving more than a small force to protect the embassy in Kabul would mean President Obama abandons his goal to bring home almost all American troops before leaving office.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: NATO soldiers at the scene of a car bomb on Sunday in Kabul, Afghanistan. NATO has 17,000 troops in Afghanistan; 9,800 of those are from the United States.

item.title: Putin Says U.S. Fails to Cooperate in Syria
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said some of Russia’s partners in Syria had “mush for brains” for failing to go along with all that Russia wanted to do.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Syrians in front of the Russian embassy in Damascus holding photographs of President Bashar Assad and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during a demonstration to thank Moscow for its intervention.

item.title: Attacks by Palestinians Kill 3 Israelis and Wound More Than 20
item.description: The assaults were the most intense eruption so far in two weeks of escalating violence that has alarmed the country and flummoxed its security forces.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Marlon James, Jamaican Novelist, Wins Man Booker Prize
item.description: Mr. James became the first Jamaican to win the prize, Britain’s top literary award, for his novel “A Brief History of Seven Killings.”
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA ALTER and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Bryan Derballa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marlon James, who won the Man Booker Prize on Tuesday for his novel "A Brief History of Seven Killings."

item.title: World Briefing: Argentina: Former Transportation Official Found Guilty in Graft Case
item.description: Ricardo Jaime was convicted after he acknowledged having accepted vacations and free rent from businessmen whose companies had government contracts.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Washington Post Reporter, Jason Rezaian, ‘Terribly Depressed’ by Conviction
item.description: Mr. Rezaian, who has been found guilty of espionage in Iran after a secret trial, learned about his conviction by watching a state television broadcast in Evin Prison.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Psychologists Are Sued Over C.I.A. Techniques
item.description: Two former detainees, along with the family of a third detainee who died while in Central Intelligence Agency custody, alleged that they were tortured.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI
